Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Adaptive plasticity, timing, and population divergence in a songbird species
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research asks how animals know whether and when to migrate and when to breed. The focal animal is a songbird in which populations with separate breeding ranges winter together but differ in whether or not they migrate. When spring arrives the non-migrants begin to breed, while the non-migrants delay breeding despite living in the same environment. Research on the mechanisms that account for different responses to identical environments could help to explain how animals monitor the environment and adjust their physiology to their needs. The dark-eyed junco is a songbird and an ideal model to address these questions.

This project will investigate plasticity in hormone systems using hormonal "challenges" and pharmacological manipulations. It will also explore differences in gene expression between resident and migratory juncos from recently diverged populations (California) and longer diverged populations (in Virginia) that over-winter together but breed in different places at different times. The prediction is that migrants will differ from residents in their response to challenges and that recently diverged populations will differ less than populations that diverged longer ago. Another prediction is that gene expression in a common garden will differ between longer diverged populations as compared with recently diverged populations.

Broader impacts
The research will enhance understanding of why and how some animals are able to thrive in changing environments, while other animals' ranges retreat, and some species are lost. This research will provide numerous opportunities to train graduate and undergraduate students, and knowledge gained will be disseminated broadly. The project will enable promotion of a documentary film starring the study species and designed for use in high schools and public venues for adult learners.

Data Management.
Data supporting results in published papers will be made available on Genbank and/or Dryad. All data generated from this research will be archived in an online repository maintained by the Indiana University Library (https://scholarworks.iu.edu/dspace/handle/2022/7911).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In seasonal environments, animals must time breeding to best match environmental conditions when offspring demand is greatest.  Thus, understanding the mechanisms regulating these timing decisions that individuals must make is of great importance.  We have studied individuals of the same species that diverge in their timing of breeding - one is resident and initiates reproductive physiology in the early spring while migrants overwinter in the same habitat and experience the same environment yet delay breeding.  Using these groups that diverge in their physiological responses to the same environment provides a key opportunity to uncover the regulatory mechanisms underlying this divergence.  We have found that in the early stages of this 'decision' making process, there is likely little impact of the hypothalamo-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis in dampening the HPG axis; residents at this time, when they were initiating reproductive physiology, had elevated baseline and stress induced glucocorticoid levels compared with migrants. This was contrary to our predictions. Recent preliminary data from our analysis of gene expression in the gonads (testes) suggest that the HPA axis may yet have an impact in later-stage timing decisions; preliminary evidence suggests glucocorticoid receptor is expressed in greater abundance in residents compared to migrants during this time when they diverge.  We further found evidence that the pituitary may serve as a critical locus for regulating the variation in early season timing responses. Resident females, who are closer to the time when they should breed, continue to elevate LH in response to repeated exposure to a hormone normally secreted by the brain (GnRH), while migrant females begin to dampen LH response in response to the same stimulation. Sex steroid negative feedback may also serve as a mechanism leading to variation and divergence; gene expression for both androgen and estrogen receptor alpha differ between residents and migrants, with migrants having elevated levels of these sex steroid receptors in the hypothalamus. Future work will be needed to investigate if this differential response to repeated GnRH stimulation is a result of pituitary ability to produce the gonadotropins, or due to sex steroid negative feedback, or other factors. 

This project has supported the training graduate students (1 MS, 2PhD), and has also partially supported the research project of one post-doc; all four trainees are women. The post-doc is now an assistant professor at a liberal arts institution, one PhD student has obtained a job in industry, and the other PhD student will defend in 2018 and begin an international post-doctoral research position in France. Several undergraduates have gained hands on research experience, and one of these students has started a graduate program at the University of Georgia. The undergraduate students supported by this award were exposed to the basic ideas of science such as hypothesis generation, experimental design, data analysis and presentation, and writing. Three of these undergraduate trainees have or will have presented results at local or international meetings. The training of these young scientist will prepare them for future work as scientist working in academia, government, industry or NGOs. Understanding the variation underlying responses to signals from the environment may have an impact in understanding how life on earth may be affected by changing environments (e.g. urbanization, land use changes). Birds are often of aesthetic value to many individuals, and understanding how to maintain healthy bird populations may provide benefits to society.  Finally, this grant enabled me to participate in outreach to American Indians as a participant in the NATURE program at NDSU, providing opportunities to interact with and encourage participation from this group traditionally underrepresented in the natural sciences.
